sn56.46:4.1: “Mendicants, the boundless desolation of interstellar space is so utterly dark that even the light of the moon and the sun, so mighty and powerful, makes no impression.”
sn56.46:5.1: When he said this, one of the mendicants asked the Buddha:
sn56.46:5.2: “Sir, that darkness really is intense, so very intense.
sn56.46:5.3: Is there any other darkness more intense and scarier than this one?”
sn56.46:6.2: “There are ascetics and brahmins who don’t truly understand about suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.
sn56.46:6.3: They take pleasure in choices that lead to rebirth …
sn56.46:6.4: They continue to make such choices …
sn56.46:6.6: Having made such choices, they fall into the darkness of rebirth, old age, and death, of sorrow, crying, pain, sadness, and distress.
sn56.46:6.7: They’re not freed from rebirth, old age, and death, from sorrow, crying, pain, sadness, and distress.
sn56.46:6.8: They’re not freed from suffering, I say.
sn56.46:7.1: There are ascetics and brahmins who truly understand about suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.
sn56.46:7.2: They don’t take pleasure in choices that lead to rebirth …
sn56.46:7.5: Having stopped making such choices, they don’t fall into the darkness of rebirth, old age, and death, of sorrow, crying, pain, sadness, and distress.
sn56.46:7.6: They’re freed from rebirth, old age, and death, from sorrow, crying, pain, sadness, and distress.
sn56.46:7.7: They’re freed from suffering, I say.
sn56.46:8.1: That’s why you should practice meditation …”
